N/A

In addition to the live virtual lectures three times a week, there were also discussion/review sessions on Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned neuro-physiology and how the neurons make connections to give us the world as we perceive it to be.

I learned about the brain and nervous system from the cellular level to the systems level. The first module was more focused on biophysical mechanisms of, for example, the action potential and synaptic transmission. The second module was more systems level, and we learned about LTP, the visual system, sensorimotor systems, and more. The final module was shortest and focused on neurodevelopment and plasticity.
I learned about the biology of neurons, the nervous systems, and how systems like the brain, heart, eyes, motor system, and sensory system function.
Learned about the molecular processes of the brain.
I was truly able to get a strong foundation in neurobiology that will prepare to pursue my own research and engage in other neuroscience courses.
so much foundational knowledge on the principles of neurobiology and popular lab techniques

This course was one of the best I have ever taken at Yale. I learned so much about the intricacy of the nervous system, and gained a much broader understanding of the seminal experiments that paved the way for neuroscience to be the field that it is today. In terms of skills, I also learned how to think about the mesmerizing things that our brain is able to do through a molecular lens. It was super interesting to understand the minute details that go into enabling all of the processing that our nervous system can do.
Basic knowledge of neurobiology concepts

I was provided a sweeping and in-depth introduction to the fundamentals of neurobiology, from the basis of action potentials to the higher-order arrangement of structures in the central nervous system.
learned a lot about the anatomical circuitry of the nervous system

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I like the structure of the lectures and the discussion sections helped clear up confusions.
The course was pretty well-organized, and covered a lot of material that was also well-taught.

One thing I absolutely did not like about the course was that I was confused half the time because I did not know how different topics were related to each other and it seemed like we were just jumping around a lot. It was only after studying for the final that I somewhat understood how things were interconnected. In my opinion, the exams (especially exam 1) were way too time crunched, and was basically testing how fast we could type instead of what we actually understood. A lot my answers (and I'm sure of others) were rushed and not very specific because of this.

There is a lot of content, but it is unclear how to prioritize what to learn. I felt that the exams tested on certain things that were less relevant or required knowing a small detail, which didn't seem to be the best thing to test. I also think the teaching styles of each professor is pretty different so that is somewhat of a harsh switch midway through the semester.

Some of this course's strengths were the incredibly fascinating material/content, the TF's (who were incredibly kind and helpful), and the Professors (who were extremely knowledgeable and accessible). The entire teaching staff was immensely supportive and provided us with many resources to not only understand the material (which was definitely challenging), but also succeed in the course.

The only weakness I would say that this course has is the fact that it has no assignments in between the exams. I felt like sometimes I only realized that I didn't fully understand a concept when I came across it in an exam. While the Professors did provide us with optional PSets that we could do for practice  which were really helpful and had questions that were definitely similar to what we saw in tests!  I almost wish that we had PSets more often so that we could practice more questions based on the content.
A strength I think is the availability of resources, including all of the review worksheets and the review sessions with the TAs.

Make sure you go to section!!!!! The course is very interesting and you learn a lot in class, but without section it is very difficult to turn all of the ideas into concrete information that you should study for the tests.
I was (and am) nervous about my grade the entire semester because there are no weekly problem sets and the average on the first exam was in the 60s. I did really enjoy the content, though.

I think that this course had extremely interesting content and covered more ground than I was expecting--which I appreciated. I think that the weak point of this course was its exam structure, relying entirely on two midterms and a final. Other MCDB courses with high content volume utilize additional teaching methods (e.g. a weekly quiz system) to facilitate greater interaction with each lecture and parcel the content in to manageable amounts. Student performance on the first exam had an extremely wide range, and I was puzzled why this wasn't acknowledged or used to guide changes to the teaching of the remaining units of this course. Given how interesting this course material was, I felt like consternation over the exams ended up being an unnecessary impediment to engaging with the content.

the first half of this course is extremely difficult and I still don't understand it, despite studying it harder than the second half. Thant might just be me, though, I'd like a more organized lesson plan if possible with the key points highlighted that way if I don't understand the explanation in lecture, i can search secondary resources on myown.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how the lecture slides and notes are posted online so we can refer to them to study.

I liked when the professors used the whiteboard function to write/draw out the notes at the same time as us (more manageable than powerpoint). Switching shares took some time, but it was ultimately helpful for students for sure.
Only complaint is that the first quiz was too long for the amount of time we had to complete it.
Not a lot of people showed up to sections, so we weren't able to have a lot of meaningful Q and A time.

I am really grateful the class was recorded because there are things mentioned in lecture that are important to hear but easy to miss. Additionally, having the TA review sessions recorded was really nice because you could listen to other TAs so if one explained a concept more clearly than another you could learn from either.
These professors and TFs were truly accommodating.
Recording were great. I think slides were personally better for me than live drawings. Also, if there are live drawings, the handouts worked well

I think this course worked super well in terms of virtual learning. The Professors and TF's recorded everything so that the lectures/sections would be accessible for everyone who couldn't make the times of the live lectures or wanted to be able to rewatch some videos while studying. They were also always extremely open and vigilant of the chat on Zoom to make sure that any questions that anyone had were addressed.
It felt pretty impersonal, but so did all of my other Zoom lectures

The course instruction on zoom was efficient and helpful. The use of digital whiteboard was very helpful and helped us understand complicated concepts. I would just suggest that the lectures stick to the allotted time, as some students have classes immediately afterwards.

I'm glad they recorded the lectures because I rewatched them, despite the first half of the semester still being hard to follow; again might jsut be me being bad at the physics and chemistry portion of the material.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course as it is very interesting and informative.

This course is actually a really great overview of neuroscience from the cellular to systems level (and is also required for the neuroscience major). It helps answer a number of the mechanistic questions about how the brain works for those who are curious. A fun time.

I have a love-hate relationship with this course. Almost every aspect of the course was painful--the lectures were very fast-paced, the material was very dense, the exams were difficult and on a time crunch. However, looking back on it, I really learned a lot about neurobiology. Whether or not I use this knowledge in my research or later in life, I think this course built my neuro knowledge foundation. So, I would recommend this course if you are required to take it, and try to look past the grades and just try to learn.
Only if you need it to graduate, otherwise it's more trouble than it's worth.
Absolutely!
its a required course for neuro students!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student who is passionate about/interested in neuroscience and wants to understand more about its cellular and molecular bases. However, I would caution students who are not STEM/neuro majors that it is not an easy course, and that you should probably go in with a solid background in biology, some background in physics and having taken The Human Brain. It is an extremely interesting course though, and the material really is fascinating. Sometimes you read the handouts and have to take a minute to digest the information, but when you step back you can't help but be in awe of the amazing things that our brain is able to do.
If you go to section and have a good section leader it is a good course, otherwise you will find yourself failing the class.

This course is ideal for students with an intrinsic interest in learning about neurobiology. If a student has this interest, I think they will find the course content engaging, interesting, unexpectedly insightful. That being said, an intrinsic interest is also essential because this course has a high content volume and the exams can be pretty unforgiving, which can dissuade students from engaging more with the material.
not unless this course is required.
